entry.et: Middle English, from Old English; akin to Old High German wintar winter and perhaps to Lithuanian vanduo water, Old English wæter water

def.dt: :the season between autumn and spring comprising in the northern hemisphere usually the months of December, January, and February or as reckoned astronomically extending from the December solstice to the March equinox
:to pass the winter winters in the Caribbean
:to feed or find food during the winter used with on
:to keep, feed, or manage during the winter
:of, relating to, or suitable for winter a winter vacation winter clothes
:sown in the autumn and harvested in the following spring or summer winter wheat winter rye compare summer
:any of several low Eurasian perennial herbs (genus Eranthis, especially E. hyemalis) of the buttercup family with solitary yellow or white flowers which often bloom through the snow
:any of several crooknecks that are winter squashes (Cucurbita moschata) noted for their keeping qualities
:a rusty-brown flounder (Pseudopleuronectes americanus of the family Pleuronectidae) of the northwestern Atlantic important as a market fish especially in winter
:to kill (as a plant) by exposure to winter conditions
:to die as a result of exposure to winter conditions
:any of several muskmelons (as a casaba or honeydew melon) that are fruits of a cultivated vine (Cucumis melo indorus)
:a large white-fleshed melon that is the fruit of an Asian vine (Benincasa hispida) and is used especially in Chinese cooking

entry.fl: noun plural but singular or plural in construction

def.dt: :a winter residence or station (as of a military unit or a circus)
:a perennial European mint (Satureja montana) with leaves used for seasoning compare summer savory
